sen.j: 戸田 忠寛（とだ ただとお、元文4年9月15日 (旧暦)（1739年10月17日） - 寛政13年1月30日 (旧暦)（1801年3月14日））は江戸時代中期の大名。
sen.e: Tadato TODA (born on October 17, 1739 and died on March 14, 1801) was a feaudal lord in the middle of the Edo Period.
Tadato TODA (October 17, 1739 - March 14, 1801) was a daimyo (feudal lord) in the middle of the Edo period.
Tadato TODA (October 17, 1739 - March 14, 1801) was a daimyo (feudal lord) in the middle of the Edo period.

sen.j: 通称は嘉十郎。
sen.e: His common name was Kajuro.
His common name was Kajuro.
His common name was Kajuro.

sen.j: 戸田氏の一門・田原戸田家9代当主。
sen.e: He was the ninth family head of the Tahara-Toda family of the Toda clan.
He was the ninth family head of the Tahara-Toda family of the Toda clan.
He was the ninth family head of the Tahara-Toda family of the Toda clan.

sen.j: 戸田氏20世孫。
sen.e: He was the 20th descendent of the Toda clan.
He was the 20th descendent of the Toda clan.
He was the 20th descendent of the Toda clan.

sen.j: 官位は従五位下侍従、因幡国守。
sen.e: His official court rank was 'Jugoinoge' (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) 'Jiju' (a chamberlain) and he was Inaba Kokushu (Governor of Inaba Province).
sen.cmt: 「従五位下侍従」の表記に自信がありません。
sen.e: His official court rank and position was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Jiju (a chamberlain), and Inaba no Kuni no kami (Governor of Inaba Province).
His official court rank and position was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Jiju (a chamberlain), and Inaba no Kuni no kami (Governor of Inaba Province).

sen.j: 肥前国島原藩第2代藩主、下野国宇都宮藩初代藩主。
sen.e: He was the second lord of of Shimabara domain, Hizen Province, and the first lord of Utsunomiya domain of the Province of Shimotsuke.
He was the second lord of Shimabara Domain, Hizen Province, and the first lord of Utsunomiya Domain of Shimotsuke Province.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。
sen.e: He was the second lord of Shimabara Domain, Hizen Province, and the first lord of Utsunomiya Domain of Shimotsuke Province.

sen.j: 宇都宮藩戸田家7代。
sen.e: He was the seventh family head of the Toda family of Utsunomiya Domain.
He was the seventh family head of the Toda family of Utsunomiya Domain.
He was the seventh family head of the Toda family of Utsunomiya Domain.

sen.j: 戸田氏18世孫で宇都宮藩戸田家5代の戸田忠余の四男として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the fourth son of Tadami TODA, the fifth family head of the Toda family of Utsunomiya Domain and as the 18th grandson of the Toda clan.
He was born as the fourth son of Tadami TODA, the fifth family head of the Toda family of Utsunomiya Domain and as the 18th descendent of the Toda clan.
He was born as the fourth son of Tadami TODA, the fifth family head of the Toda family of Utsunomiya Domain and as the 18th descendent of the Toda clan.

sen.j: 正室は本多正珍の娘。
sen.e: His legal wife was a daughter of Masayoshi HONDA.
His legal wife was a daughter of Masayoshi HONDA.
His legal wife was a daughter of Masayoshi HONDA.

sen.j: 子に戸田忠翰（長男）、田中忠舜（次男）、娘（永井尚佐正室）。
sen.e: His children were Tadanaka TODA (the eldest son), Tadakiyo TANAKA (the second son) and a daughter (Naosuke NAGAI's legal wife).
His children were Tadanaka TODA (the oldest son), Tadakiyo TANAKA (the second son) and a daughter (Naosuke NAGAI's legal wife).
His children were Tadanaka TODA (the oldest son), Tadakiyo TANAKA (the second son) and a daughter (Naosuke NAGAI's legal wife).

sen.j: 養女に戸田忠喬正室（戸田忠盈の娘）、堀直方正室（木下利胤の娘）。
sen.e: His adopted daughters were Tadataka TODA's legal wife (Tadamitsu TODA's daughter) and Naokata HORI's legal wife (Toshitsune KINOSHITA's daughter).
His adopted daughters were Tadataka TODA's legal wife (Tadamitsu TODA's daughter) and Naokata HORI's legal wife (Toshitsune KINOSHITA's daughter).
His adopted daughters were Tadataka TODA's legal wife (Tadamitsu TODA's daughter) and Naokata HORI's legal wife (Toshitsune KINOSHITA's daughter).

sen.j: 家督相続の後、大坂城代、京都所司代といった要職を歴任する。
sen.e: When he inherited the family estate, he served in a variety of high-ranking government posts, including Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle) and Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy).
When he inherited the family estate, he served in a variety of high-ranking government posts, including Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka-jo Castle) and Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy).
When he inherited the family estate, he served in a variety of high-ranking government posts, including Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka-jo Castle) and Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy).

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Life
Biography
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: Biography

sen.j: 兄・戸田忠盈に男子はあったが、夭逝した為に宝暦4年（1754年）5月、嗣子となった。
sen.e: Because of the premature mortality of the son of his elder brother, Tadamitsu TODA, Tadato became the heir on May, 1754.
Because of the premature mortality of the son of his older brother, Tadamitsu TODA, Tadato became the heir on June, 1754.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。
sen.e: Because of the premature mortality of the son of his older brother, Tadamitsu TODA, Tadato became the heir on June, 1754.

sen.j: 同年7月、襲封して肥前国島原藩主となり、従五位下因幡守に叙せられた。
sen.e: On July, the same year, he inherited the territories to become the lord of Shimabara domain, Hizen Province and was given the status of 'Jugoinoge Inaba no kami (unior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, Governor of Inaba Province).'
sen.cmt: 「従五位下因幡守」の表記に自信がありません。
sen.e: On August, the same year, he inherited the territories to become the lord of Shimabara Domain, Hizen Province and was given the status of Jugoinoge Inaba no kami.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、統一リストに合わせ、前出補足を削除しました。
sen.e: On August, the same year, he inherited the territories to become the lord of Shimabara Domain, Hizen Province and was given the status of Jugoinoge Inaba no kami.

sen.j: 翌年の宝暦6年（1756年）、はじめて城地に帰る。
sen.e: The following year, in 1756, he returned to his castellany for the first time.
The following year, in 1756, he returned to his castellany for the first time.
The following year, in 1756, he returned to his castellany for the first time.

sen.j: 明和7年（1770年）、奏者番となる。
sen.e: In 1770, he became 'sojaban' (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
In 1770, he became Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。
sen.e: In 1770, he became Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).

sen.j: 安永3年（1774年）、領地を転じて下野国宇都宮藩主となり、宇都宮城を居城とする。
sen.e: In 1774, he was transferred to Utsunomiya domain of the Province of Shimotsuke and lived in the Utsunomiya-jo Castle.
In 1774, he was transferred to Utsunomiya Domain in Shimotsuke Province and resided in the Utsunomiya-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせ表現を変えました。
sen.e: In 1774, he was transferred to Utsunomiya Domain in Shimotsuke Province and resided in the Utsunomiya-jo Castle.

sen.j: 江戸幕府より5,000両を借りて城を造営し、同5年（1776年）、寺社奉行を兼ねて、天明2年（1782年）9月、大坂城代となる。
sen.e: He borrowed 5,000 'ryo (currency unit)' from Edo bakufu to build a castle, and on September, 1776, he became 'Osaka jodai' (the keeper of Osaka Castle) as well as 'jisha-bugyo' (magistrate of temples and shrines).
sen.cmt: 「城を造営」とありますが、どの城を造営したのか、分かりませんでした。
sen.e: He borrowed 5,000 ryo (currency unit) from Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to build a castle, appointed to jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) in 1776, and then in October, 1782, he also served additional position as Osaka jodai.
sen.cmt: 訳もれ。年号補足しました。統一リストに合わせ表現を変えました。
sen.e: He borrowed 5,000 ryo (currency unit) from Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to build a castle, appointed to jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) in 1776, and then in October, 1782, he also served additional position as Osaka jodai.

sen.j: 同年、旧領改め、河内国、播磨国に所領を移封され、同4年（1784年）5月、京都所司代に補任し侍従に任官する。
sen.e: In the same year, he was transferred to Kawachi and Harima Provinces and on May, 1784, he was appointed as 'Kyoto Shoshidai' and 'Jiju.'
In the same year, he was transferred to Kawachi and Harima Provinces and on June, 1784, he was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai and Jiju.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、表記を変えました。
sen.e: In the same year, he was transferred to Kawachi and Harima Provinces and on June, 1784, he was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai and Jiju.

sen.j: 同年9月、所領を河内国、摂津国に移され、同7年（1787年）12月、所司代を辞し、旧領宇都宮に転封となる。
sen.e: On September, the same year, he was transferred to Kawachi and Settsu Provinces and on December, 1787, he resigned the post of 'Shoshidai' and was transferred to his old domain, Utsunomiya.
In October, the same year, he was transferred to Kawachi and Settsu Provinces and in January, 1788, he resigned the post of Shoshidai and was transferred to his old territory, Utsunomiya Domain.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、表現を変えました。
sen.e: In October, the same year, he was transferred to Kawachi and Settsu Provinces and in January, 1788, he resigned the post of Shoshidai and was transferred to his old territory, Utsunomiya Domain.

sen.j: この年に、京都伏見にて市人争訟の儀あったが、その計らいが不十分であったとされ、出仕が停められた。
sen.e: In that year, although Tadato dealt with a lawsuit between merchants in Fushimi, Kyoto, his dealings were considered insufficient and he was prohibited from attending the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: どこへの「出仕」が停められたのか分かりませんでした。「宮廷への出仕」としております。
sen.e: In that year, although Tadato dealt with a lawsuit between merchants in Fushimi, Kyoto, his dealings were considered insufficient and he was prohibited from attending the Imperial Court.
In that year, although Tadato dealt with a lawsuit between merchants in Fushimi, Kyoto, his dealings were considered insufficient and he was prohibited from attending the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 間もなく免ぜられ、寛政10年（1798年）6月21日に致仕・隠居した。
sen.e: He was relieve of his post before long and on June 21, 1798 he resigned and retired to his family estate.
Soon he was excused from it then resigned the service and retired on August 3, 1798.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、表現を変えました。
sen.e: Soon he was excused from it then resigned the service and retired on August 3, 1798.

sen.j: 同13年（1801年）正月晦日に没する。
sen.e: He passed away on the last day of January, 1801.
He passed away on February 13, 1801.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。
sen.e: He passed away on February 13, 1801.

sen.j: 享年63。
sen.e: He passed away at the age of 63.
Died at the age of 63.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: Died at the age of 63.

sen.j: 墓は宇都宮英厳寺。
sen.e: His grave was in Eigen-ji Temple, Utsunomiya.
His grave was located in Eigen-ji Temple, Utsunomiya.
His grave was located in Eigen-ji Temple, Utsunomiya.

sen.j: 戒名は霊鳳院殿輝峯全徳大居士。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name was Reihoinden Kihozentoku Daikoji.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Reihoinden Kihozentoku Daikoji.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Reihoinden Kihozentoku Daikoji.
